name.text: Limit of a Function at a Specific Point

questiontext.text:
You are given that the function \(f(x)\) satisfies the inequality,

\({@fleft@} \leq f(x) \leq {@fright@}\) for \(x \leq {@cc@}\)

Determine the value of \(\displaystyle \lim_{x \rightarrow {@cc@}} f(x)\)

\(\displaystyle \lim_{x \rightarrow {@cc@}} f(x) =\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

[[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked solution

We can find \(\displaystyle \lim_{x \rightarrow {@cc@}} f(x)\) using the "Squeeze Theorem", as follows,

\({@fleft@} \leq f(x) \leq {@fright@} \Rightarrow \displaystyle \lim_{x \rightarrow {@cc@}}({@fleft@}) \leq \lim_{x \rightarrow {@cc@}}f(x) \leq \lim_{x \rightarrow {@cc@}}({@fright@})\)

Then, we can compute the two bounding limits,

{@simp:false;@}

\(\displaystyle \lim_{x \rightarrow {@cc@}}({@fleft@}) = {@aa@} \cdot {@cc + bb@} = {@sqval@}\)

\(\displaystyle \lim_{x \rightarrow {@cc@}}({@fright@}) = {@line1@} = {@sqval@}\)

{@simp:true;@}

Therefore, since both of these limits exist and are equal, the Squeeze Theorem tells us that the limit of \(f(x)\) exists, and is equal to the limit of its bounding functions.

Hence, \(\displaystyle \lim_{x \rightarrow {@cc@}} f(x) = {@sqval@}\)

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.
